publicationStmt.publisher: The Characters that shaped the Silk Road - A Database and Digital Paleography of Tarim

history.provenance: found in Šorčuqduring T III Š 64.15

seg.seg: “... the dignity of the Omniscient (has) been (given) to you, for the sake of which you have abandoned me, the innocent one. I, who have been brought up as a Kṣatriya [and] grown up in happiness, (endure ?) suffer(ing) ....
The infernal sufferings I endure [lit. see] (already) among humans. In my disheveled hair curls everywhere animals have made nest[s] ...
me by day and night. 2. Dear ... creatures! If only you may see my misfortune and ill-usage! ....
Dear (forest?) beings!, may you see my misery and misfortune!
Forlorn I wander in the forest. T(here I lie (?)) on the ground, wrapped in feathers of the kotstse (or kautstse) bird, nobody’s kin. ....
O lord, father!” 3. Thereupon prince Uttara ... remember(ing (?)) .... like ....
(fal)len, (sprinkling) dust onto [his] head, he speaks: || (In) [the tune] bharyacin(tāk ||)
.... (not?) helpful, the life .... Life, oh you disgraceful one ....
without shelter [and] refuge. Oh god Karman, why do you (demonstrate ??) [your] power so much on me? .... restrained. (2.) ....
O Gott Karman, warum (zeig)st du so sehr [deine] Macht an mir?
Oh god Karman, why do you (sh)ow [your] power so greatly on me?
to see. (It is) [both] happiness [and] suffering to me to have partaken in this your domain. Yet I, having suffered now, ....
in (su)ffering. 3. Thereupon now merchants of Aruṇāvatī (having heard) the prince Uttara’s lamenting [and] wo(rds, speaking to one another:)
“Who is it that laments so pitifully [and] calls out the name of the lord, of king Araṇemi?” The merchant Dravyeśvara (speaks): “ ....
Who may be wailing so pitifully, calling the name of the lord, king Araṇemi? (cf 319)
Wer klagt da wohl [so] erbärmlich [wtl. mitleidig] und ruft den Namen des Herrn, des Königs Araṇemi?
Who [is it that] is crying here so pitifully and is calling the name of the lord, of king Araṇemi?
an (unhappy ??) creature.” The merchant Maṇīśvara speaks: “Some tender voice is heard [here]. Never ever before have I (heard) such [a voice] from a human.” ...
Der Kaufmann Maṇīśvara spricht: "Irgendeine zarte Stimme wird da gehört. Noch nie (habe ich) so etwas [wtl. jenes] von einem Menschen (gehört)."
The merchant Maṇīśvara speaks: "Some tender voice is heard here. Never before (have I heard) the like of it [lit. that] from a human."

p.note: Continues , continued on , after a gap of undeterminable length.
The lament of prince Uttara. The translation basically follows 318-319.

Between this and there is a gap of 18 leaves. Into this gap belongs fragment , which certainly does not follow immediately, as well as the Uyghur text Mainz 223, which is taken from a manuscript collection of the Berlin Turfan collection (cf. U 2293).

āklu is edited as ā[k]lu by Sieg/Siegling; the akṣara 〈klu〉 is preservered very clearly, but the shape of the upper sign 〈k〉, admittedly, is a bit odd, looking more like a 〈na〉; however, it is completely clear that āklu is meant and the sign is sloppily written rather than a genuine copying error.
According to Sieg/Siegling, the meter has 4x18 syllables (7/7/4).

The interpretation by Thomas 242f. (followed by 318) is certainly wrong ("In [ihren] ausgebreiteten Haaren gewährten mir die Tiere überall Unterkunft"); first, letse means "human head hair" or rather "curls" and in other passages even has attributes like ‘beautiful'; so it can hardly refer to animal fur. Secondly, the point of the passage is Uttara's miserable condition, entirely deprived of any help whatsoever. Accordingly, one should rather follow the interpretation by 560 s.v. lesto and letse given here.

318 proposes to restore an adjective ‘forest' ("(Wald)wesen"); the visible top of the last akṣara may indeed belong to a 〈ṣa〉, but since the word cannot have more than two syllables, the form cannot be restored to wärttoṣṣi 'pertaining to the forest'.
Sieg/Siegling propose to restore t(ane ñiś\ lyakau). They also note that the damaged hapax k[o]tsts[e]ṃts may alternatively be read k[au]tsts[e]ṃts.
āptsa for āṣtsa 'onto the head' is a copying error.
According to Sieg/Siegling, this is the tune bharyacin(tāk) with a metre of 4x12 syllables (4/4/4).

One can actually read more on the manuscript than has been done before. However, word separation and metrical analysis of pāda 1c still remains uncertain, the more since the quite certain four-syllabic (e)kitatse is metrically imcompatible with the following six akṣaras. Thomas 243 and 319 with fn. 110) propose to separate śaulyñe ‘life', which would be an analogical form based on śail(y)ñe ‘life' (see 140). A guess for the remaining akṣaras may be [c](ä)(ñ)c(aṃ)-m(e) ‘pleases them', but I cannot make much sense of this form here.

Both 460f. and Thomas 243 correctly argue that the old restoration (lkā)st(a)r is unlikely, because the grundverb has no causative meaning (at least in the present stem). The correct restoration of the verbal form remains uncertain.
The traditional restoration to an infinitive yā(mtsi) cannot be correct, because one sees the lower part of the sign, which belongs to a 〈ka〉 or 〈u〉-vowel. The PPt of yām- ist most likely.

I think läkā- 'to see' is here used like in the phrase läklenta läkā- 'to endure sufferings' and not to be taken literally (as, e.g., by 319 "feindselig angesehen"). At the end of the line Thomas 243 proposes the restoration re(kauna keklyauṣormeṃ ālyauceś weskeṃ.
Note the reverse spelling käryaurtto for käryorttau! In the following, ksa and tamp also show wrong vowels.
319 seems to restore (tallā)nt onolme "an unhappy creature" (obl.sg).

Alternative classifications:
Peyrot–
Malzahn–
TamaiII-3 (800-900)
Tamai-C14–

Translations from [[Peyrot, ToSu]]
Lines Translation Pages
a3 Dear (forest?) beings!, may you see my misery and misfortune! 356
b5 Who may be wailing so pitifully, calling the name of the lord, king Araṇemi? (cf [[Schmidt KT 2001]]: 319) 353

Translations from [[Schmidt KT 1974]]
Lines Translation Pages
b2 O Gott Karman, warum (zeig)st du so sehr [deine] Macht an mir? 460
b5 Wer klagt da wohl [so] erbärmlich [wtl. mitleidig] und ruft den Namen des Herrn, des Königs Araṇemi? 383
b6 Der Kaufmann Maṇīśvara spricht: "Irgendeine zarte Stimme wird da gehört. Noch nie (habe ich) so etwas [wtl. jenes] von einem Menschen (gehört)." 217-8

b3 was "to me to (having) partake". Meant is that after his happiness Uttara has now also seen suffering, and so the whole range of god Karman.Michael (Wed, 2016-04-20, 13:24:57 (CEST))

a1 “... the dignity of the Omniscient (has) been (given) to you, for the sake of which you have abandoned me, the innocent one. I, who have been brought up as a Kṣatriya [and] grown up in happiness, (endure ?) suffer(ing) .... a2 The infernal sufferings I endure [lit. see] (already) among humans. In my disheveled hair curls everywhere animals have made nest[s] ... a3 me by day and night. 2. Dear ... creatures! If only you may see my misfortune and ill-usage! .... a4 Forlorn I wander in the forest. T(here I lie (?)) on the ground, wrapped in feathers of the kotstse (or kautstse) bird, nobody’s kin. .... a5 O lord, father!” 3. Thereupon prince Uttara ... remember(ing (?)) .... like .... a6 (fal)len, (sprinkling) dust onto [his] head, he speaks: || (In) [the tune] bharyacin(tāk ||) b1 .... (not?) helpful, the life .... Life, oh you disgraceful one .... b2 without shelter [and] refuge. Oh god Karman, why do you (demonstrate ??) [your] power so much on me? .... restrained. (2.) .... b3 to see. (It is) [both] happiness [and] suffering to me to have partaken in this your domain. Yet I, having suffered now, .... b4 in (su)ffering. 3. Thereupon now merchants of Aruṇāvatī (having heard) the prince Uttara’s lamenting [and] wo(rds, speaking to one another:) b5 “Who is it that laments so pitifully [and] calls out the name of the lord, of king Araṇemi?” The merchant Dravyeśvara (speaks): “ .... b6 an (unhappy ??) creature.” The merchant Maṇīśvara speaks: “Some tender voice is heard [here]. Never ever before have I (heard) such [a voice] from a human.” ...

Continues [[THT 88]], continued on [[THT 90]], after a gap of undeterminable length.

The lament of prince Uttara. The translation basically follows [[Schmidt KT 2001]]: 318-319.

Between this and [[THT 91]] there is a gap of 18 leaves. Into this gap belongs fragment [[THT 90]], which certainly does not follow [[THT 89]] immediately, as well as the Uyghur text Mainz 223, which is taken from a manuscript collection of the Berlin Turfan collection (cf. U 2293).

a1 āklu is edited as ā[k]lu by Sieg/Siegling; the akṣara 〈klu〉 is preservered very clearly, but the shape of the upper sign 〈k〉, admittedly, is a bit odd, looking more like a 〈na〉; however, it is completely clear that āklu is meant and the sign is sloppily written rather than a genuine copying error.

a1-a5 According to Sieg/Siegling, the meter has 4x18 syllables (7/7/4).

a2 The interpretation by Thomas [[TochSprR(B)2]]: 242f. (followed by [[Schmidt KT 2001]]: 318) is certainly wrong ("In [ihren] ausgebreiteten Haaren gewährten mir die Tiere überall Unterkunft"); first, letse means "human head hair" or rather "curls" and in other passages even has attributes like ‘beautiful'; so it can hardly refer to animal fur. Secondly, the point of the passage is Uttara's miserable condition, entirely deprived of any help whatsoever. Accordingly, one should rather follow the interpretation by [[Adams, DoT]]: 560 s.v. lesto and letse given here.

a3 [[Schmidt KT 2001]]: 318 proposes to restore an adjective ‘forest' ("(Wald)wesen"); the visible top of the last akṣara may indeed belong to a 〈ṣa〉, but since the word cannot have more than two syllables, the form cannot be restored to wärttoṣṣi 'pertaining to the forest'.

a4 Sieg/Siegling propose to restore t(ane ñiś\ lyakau). They also note that the damaged hapax k[o]tsts[e]ṃts may alternatively be read k[au]tsts[e]ṃts.

a6 āptsa for āṣtsa 'onto the head' is a copying error.

a6, b1-b4 According to Sieg/Siegling, this is the tune bharyacin(tāk) with a metre of 4x12 syllables (4/4/4).

b1 One can actually read more on the manuscript than has been done before. However, word separation and metrical analysis of pāda 1c still remains uncertain, the more since the quite certain four-syllabic (e)kitatse is metrically imcompatible with the following six akṣaras. Thomas [[TochSprR(B)2]]: 243 and [[Schmidt KT 2001]]: 319 with fn. 110) propose to separate śaulyñe ‘life', which would be an analogical form based on śail(y)ñe ‘life' (see [[Peyrot 2008]]: 140). A guess for the remaining akṣaras may be [c](ä)(ñ)c(aṃ)-m(e) ‘pleases them', but I cannot make much sense of this form here.

b2 Both [[Schmidt KT 1974]]: 460f. and Thomas [[TochSprR(B)2]]: 243 correctly argue that the old restoration (lkā)st(a)r is unlikely, because the grundverb has no causative meaning (at least in the present stem). The correct restoration of the verbal form remains uncertain.

b3 The traditional restoration to an infinitive yā(mtsi) cannot be correct, because one sees the lower part of the sign, which belongs to a 〈ka〉 or 〈u〉-vowel. The PPt of yām- ist most likely.

b4 I think läkā- 'to see' is here used like in the phrase läklenta läkā- 'to endure sufferings' and not to be taken literally (as, e.g., by [[Schmidt KT 2001]]: 319 "feindselig angesehen"). At the end of the line Thomas [[TochSprR(B)2]]: 243 proposes the restoration re(kauna keklyauṣormeṃ ālyauceś weskeṃ.

b6 [[Schmidt KT 2001]]: 319 seems to restore (tallā)nt onolme "an unhappy creature" (obl.sg).

a1 tka-c perne poyśiññe ket pernesa snai t_r_aṅko ñiś rinsatai : kṣatriññempa āklu ñi_ś\ sakne aukṣu _l_akl[e] /// a2 nraiṣṣana toṃ _l_aklenta yśāmna lk[ā]skau : waiptā_r\ wlo_ṣ_aṃ letseṃne po _k_alymintsa lwāsa ñi lestai yāmwa : /// a3 ñi iṅkauṃ _k_astwe_r\ 2 la○reñä\ (–) ·i onolmi lkoycer nai ñi tallārñe erka[tñ](·) /// a4 triku yam warttone : keṃtsa ○ [t](· – – – – –) k[o]tsts[e]ṃts [p]arwa tat·āṅ[k]au mā ketrā[ññe] /// a5 sasw= appakka 3 || tumeṃ uttar(·) mñcuṣke [na] (– – – – – – –) – e[pi]ya (– – – –) – ram (·)o /// a6 [yau] taur āptsa _k_a – (–) ·e we_ṣ_ṣ_aṃ || bharyaci[n](·) /// b1 kitatse śaulyñe [c](· ·)[c](·) m(·) ·n(·) • śaul oṅkipṣu [k](·) /// b2 snai saim waste : yāmor ñakta kā tot ñiśne maiyya (–)st(·)[_r]\ (– – –) ·s(·) ye – (– – – –) s[a]ññ[ā]_t\ /// b3 lkātsi : ñi sak lakle [t](·)ñ w(·)○[ṣ](·) tu [p]āke yā(·) – [y](·)k no ñi_ś\ ñke erk(·)tñettse lye[l]·[w] e /// b4 klene 3 || tane ñake āru○ṇāvatiṣṣi _k_aryo(·)tt(·)ñcä\ uttari mñcuṣkeṃtse t_r_aṅkalyñe [re] /// b5 k_use nai tam_p\• añmālaṣke palwaṃ _s_asweṃtse araṇemiñ lānte _ṣ_p_a ñe_m\ śau_ś_aṃ || dravyaśvare _k_aryo(·)tt· /// b6 nt onolme || maṇiśvare _k_aryaurtto we_ṣ_ṣ_aṃ lalaṃṣke ksā sam_p\ we_k\ klyauṣt_r_a mā tām_p\ nta ykāka śaumoṃntse ///
b6 Note the reverse spelling käryaurtto for käryorttau! In the following, ksa and tamp also show wrong vowels.

div.p:
Alternative classifications:

was "to me to (having) partake". Meant is that after his happiness Uttara has now also seen suffering, and so the whole range of god Karman.Michael (Wed, 2016-04-20, 13:24:57 (CEST))
